issues.description: The problem statement text (line 50) instructs students to implement addGuestStudents(String), but the UML diagram (lines 72-73) and the solution both define addGuestStudents(int): void. This is a parameter type mismatch that will confuse students about the correct method signature to implement and will likely cause their implementation to fail tests if they follow the textual instruction.
issues.suggested_fix: Unify the method signature across the artifacts. The simplest fix is to correct the problem statement text at line 50 to require addGuestStudents(int) rather than addGuestStudents(String). Alternatively, if a String parameter was intended, update the UML and the solution to use addGuestStudents(String) and document how to parse/handle the string — but keeping an int parameter is clearer for representing a number of students.

issues.description: The problem text (line 50) refers to addGuestStudents(String) while the UML in the same problem statement and the solution implementation define addGuestStudents(int). This mismatch (String vs int) in the method signature for the same conceptual operation can confuse students about the expected parameter type and what to implement.
issues.suggested_fix: Fix the problem statement to use the same method signature as the UML and solution: change the textual description from addGuestStudents(String) to addGuestStudents(int). Optionally, include a short parameter name (e.g. numberOfNewGuestStudents) in the problem text to match the solution and clarify expected behavior. Also consider adding an explicit method stub with the int parameter to the template to make the expectation unambiguous.
